+Donald Kasper
Sir, your response is 100% incorrect and your position denies modern 
progress in science as well as other disciplines (perhaps you are Amish? If 
so then you are welcome to live like 1690 but your position reflects your 
chosen point of view, not humanity's after the age of enlightenment). You 
denigrate "algorithms" but they are mathematical abstractions (think 
recipes) based upon the programmer's understanding of the subject being 
modeled. There are ~ 25 competing climate models and they can all hind-cast 
climate over the previous 100 years which proves that algorithms are 
fundamentally correct. Future casting is more difficult since computers 
can't account for unknown climate changing events like volcanic explosions 
or man-made fires to clear new agricultural land (to only name two points 
of many). But do not take my word for this. Here are what scientists think 
about climate models: 
http://www.skepticalscience.com/climate-models-intermediate.htm

+Neil Rieck
Very cute except that there are no climate models, as they predict 
nothing.  They are historical temperature data retrofit computer algorithms 
that throw a bunch of equations of state at a bunch of temperature records, 
and use supercomputers to calculate until there is a match.  Sort of like 
throwing oatmeal at the wall to see what sticks.  When they get a match, 
they can use this model to run forward.  If the model is accurate, there 
will be some variation around actual records, sometimes a bit high and 
sometimes a bit low.  Is this what we get?  No.  The models immediately 
diverge from the climate record.  Over time it gets worse.  Then worse.  
Then worse.  To infinity and beyond, just worse.  What does this show?  
There is no correlation whatsoever in any sense of the word between the 
models and observations.  So, we have to conclude they are not models.  
They are just numerical coincidences as artifacts of enough forced 
equational fits where by shithouse random chance, once now and again they 
get a match.  Sort of like have a computer generate infinite number 
combinations until they match the latest Lotto numbers does not mean they 
should be used to predict future Lottos.  They are not a tad off of 100% in 
their prediction.  They are total shithouse filthy goddamned trash to such 
a preposterous level of stupidity that we should not waste brain cells even 
discussing their existence.  From this, you get model science denial.  
Damn, that is hilarious.  You are obviously a man of faith, but not much on 
science.

Science advances through the phases of: Observation, Hypothesis, Experiment 
(test), Debate. Then publish and repeat. During the experiment phase, 
scientists always build models to see if the hypothesis is sensible and 
reasonable accurate (but the models are not proof; the next set of 
observations are). For example, mechanical models were built to describe 
planetary motion. Scientists knew epicycles where wrong but were afraid to 
speak out against the prevailing dogma held by the Vatican circa 1610. 
Mathematical models were built by people like Urbain Le Verrier to predict 
the position of a missing data term which would later be named Neptune. 
Einstein used "general relativity" to correct the mathematical model of the 
motion of Mercury so it would match what astronomers observed with their 
instruments (and yet many scientists refused to believe "relativity" for 
decades). The same is happening with climate change. The planet is warming 
for various reasons and ~25 working climate models are one proof that 
scientific  hypothesis is in the correct direction. Are they 100% accurate 
in their future predictions? No. Are they 99% accurate in hind-casting 
using already collected information? Pretty much.  So are you with the 
pragmatic scientists or are you with the dogmatic science-deniers?

Back in 1968, people saw a fictional HAL-9000 winning while playing chess 
against a human in the movie 2001; I remember most people scoffed at the 
idea. Ten years later people were buying computer chess machines at Radio 
Shack. By 1996, IBM's DeepBlue beat world champion chess master Gary 
Kasparov. This side of Y2K, Ford has self parking cars, Google has a 
prototype self-driving car, and IBM has morphed their Jeopardy playing 
system known as Watson into a Doctor's Assistant. QUESTION: Is modelling 
Earth's climate easier or harder than these examples I have just given? 
ANSWER: I don't know so I'll leave it up to the experts who say this: all 
25 of the popular climate model software packages can hind-cast 
climate-change correctly going back to 1900 (they don't bother going back 
past that point because direct measurements from that time are incomplete). 
Now if simulations of this kind warned us of an impending collision with an 
asteroid or comet then I think most people would be concerned. So what's 
the problem with climate change? Is the health of that artificial construct 
called the  economy so important that it trumps all other debate? Perhaps 
it has more to do with the politicization of science.

or maybe a thousand or two (out of billions) will ever read those words.

pollution and greenhouse gases human beings are responsible for is having a 
direct effect on the planet and its climate is as clear as day. It adds up; 
it makes sense. The points you brought up may or may not be relevant, and 
even if they are or could be, the degree to which they are relevant is 
unknown. 

Pointing out that we cannot stop earthquakes is a strawman argument because 
it turns the argument about climate into an argument about tectonic plates, 
which is not what the argument is about and which is completely irrelevant.

complete control over the universe. True. But again, no one on the climate 
change side is arguing that point. So why bring it up? It's just a 
distraction. Or is that the intention - to distract from the actual issue 
at hand? Why would you do that? If there's a real and verifiable problem at 
hand that threatens the wellbeing of our species - and all living things on 
the planet - and that problem will only grow worse over time if little or 
nothing is done to address that problem, why would you take action to delay 
or throw off track potential or actual solutions to that problem? Isn't 
that the same thing as purposely perpetuating the problem?

that; became aware of that saying decades ago. That doesn't mean that the 
"opinion" that the man-made climate change we see happening and that we see 
accelerating is an "opinion" that "stinks" anymore than the "opinion" that 
the earth is round, or that the theory of gravity or the theory of 
evolution (neither of which are considered theories anymore) stinks. 

Science doesn't set forth ideas without solid evidence. Determining the 
source of creation is something science is still figuring out. But that 
doesn't mean it won't. We haven't cured cancer yet, but we've made headway, 
especially of late. We haven't cured AIDS but we've turned it from a 
death-sentence to a manageable disease (and various vaccines are in the 
process of being tested.) 

That people choose to believe or disbelieve in science is their right. You 
and I have the right to believe whatever we want to, so long as it doesn't 
harm ourselves or others. But I think that denying the fact that us humans 
are responsible for the climate change that is going on right now is or 
will cause all of us harm.

I WISH this wasn't so; I wish the climate wasn't changing or at least that

times, two different things, and it would be both foolish if not

Water vapor is the main greenhouse gas but it is temperature driven. (It 
is, actually, extremely dry at the poles) CO2 and other "dry" greenhouse 
gases are what moderate temperature. There was a study done 6 years ago or 
so that concluded, using computer models, that if CO2 were to be entirely 
removed from the atmosphere, global temperature would drop dramatically, 
and within a decade the earth would be covered with ice. Search YouTube for 
"how climate works" and watch the lecture given by David Randall. A few 
other things to consider. According to well established physics equations, 
for every doubling of CO2 there is a increase of 4 watts per square meter 
of downward (from the atmosphere) re-emitted infrared (heat energy), on 
average, over the entire planet. See any video by Scott Denning. We are 
adding CO2 faster than it can be taken up naturally. The Mauna Loa CO2 
graph shows this. Go to coursera.com, register for David Archer's global 
warming course and watch the videos. Dr. Archer also talks about something 
that receives little attention in the media. It is called "the long tail". 
Basically, CO2 will hang around in the atmosphere for hundreds of thousands 
of years. It is taken out of the atmosphere via natural processes like 
weathering and absorption into oceans very slowly. So global warming is 
really centuries long problem. The hiatus in warming over the past 18 years 
is very interesting to read and think about. There "appears" to be a hiatus 
partly due to cherry picking the start of this period (end of a very strong 
el Nino), followed by a long sequence of el Ninas, and a change in trade 
winds that caused the oceans to draw down more heat than usual. I would 
recommend starting with the Wikipedia article. There was a study by 
scientists that showed that if you use the most current state of the art 
computer models and start with the conditions in 1998, the models will 
predict the "apparent" hiatus in global surface warming. Scientists say if 
you take that extra energy the oceans have absorbed into account there 
really is no hiatus.

+Robert Beal The top emitters of CO2 are the tropical rain forests and 
termites. In terms of CO2 radiance, it operates on one small spectral band. 
Volume of any gas is a tough problem as the volume is related to pressure 
and that is related to temperature. It is not just a volume of gas, but a 
pressure at a specific temperature. So they have things like STP, standard 
temperature-pressure calibration to relate volumes to reactions. A rising 
parcel of gas has less pressure, so it expands. This reduces the 
concentration. Reduced concentrations have greater than linear reduction in 
reaction rates, often exponentially less.

There has never been a graph of CO2 to global mean temperature with a trend 
line fit, as there is no correlation. In time series, they are comparing 
the rate of increase of CO2 and the rate of increase of temperature and 
saying they can be scaled to look like the same rates, and therefore they 
are related. But that is not cause-and-effect. To do that you graph CO2 to 
global mean temperature. There is no correlation. CO2 concentration is not 
related to global mean temperature and this is why no one does the graph to 
prove it. They cannot. They can only compare rates of increase to pretend 
this is a gas volume constant state equation relationship, which it is not.
